item.title: Everything is 4 in English Network Graph
item.description: When you take any word in English and count its letters, then count the number of letters in that numeral and so on, you'll end up at 4.

item.title: Almost every 3rd Monacan is a Millionaire
item.description: According to research from WealthInsight these are the world's top 20 cities with the highest millionaire density. Monaco leads the pack followed by Zurich and Geneva.

item.title: Gender Comparison: Would you Tell your Weight?
item.description: A look at the results of a poll about whether people disclose their body weight and how to present results of such a pool using data visualization.

item.title: Who Engages more in Fatal Stupidity: Men or Women?
item.description: A recent study evaluated the sex differences in idiotic behavior by looking at the gender of 318 Darwin Award winners from 1995 to 2014.

item.title: Daily Calorie Intake in the US from 1970-2010
item.description: A stacked area graph to visualize the evolution of calorie intake by food group from 1970-2010 in the United States.

item.title: What Area can you Buy for $1M in different US Cities
item.description: A set of data visualizations that display what area of land you could buy for 1 million US dollar in different US cities.

item.title: What Age Do Musicians Die at
item.description: A look at the distributions of musicians' ages of death for different causes of death, musical genres and instruments played, visualized with Google Chart Tools.

item.title: GitHub Commit Map
item.description: A geographic map that displays location information extracted from GitHub commit data grouped by the countries of the world.

item.title: Web Browser Word Clouds from GitHub Commit Messages
item.description: Visualization of GitHub commit messages with web browser mentions as word clouds created with the D3.js JavaScript library.

item.title: Programming Language Influence by Paradigm Gallery
item.description: Visualizing the influence of programming languages within various programming paradigms using directed network graphs.
